comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'm not convinced that the track has actually been laid in this photo - the rails look more than five feet apart and besides no sleepers, I can't see any seats for the rails. I suspect this of being a publicity shot announcing the opening of the tunnel before it was actually finished.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
"The Westport line was extended to Achill Sound in the 1890s. and this was one of the so-called 'Balfour Lines', called after Arthur J. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland during the years 1887-91, who introduced the Act providing State assistance for the construction of narrow gauge lines to disadvantaged areas. The first station on this extension was Newport which opened in February 1894, followed by Mallaranny, (Mulranny) in August of the same year. The line to Achill was completed in May 1895."

It's definitely not narrow gauge in the picture.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: mgwr.weebly.com/newport-station.html "The line was not opened until 1894 on completion of a nearby tunnel at the end of Newport Station" So post 1892 and pre 1894, I'd guess.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Freeman's of Friday, June 15, 1894 reports at great length on the "Appalling disaster near Westport" in which an overladen ship capsized and forty people were drowned, many from Achill. One of the problems was the conveyance of the bodies from Westport to Achill.
Mr A M O'Malley, JP, Lloyd's agent here, having wired to the manager MGW Railway Company as to the desirability of giving trucks for the conveyance of the dead bodies over the new line of railway (not yet open) from Westport to Achill Sound, Mr Tatlow promptly replied, placing trucks for the disposal of the friends of the deceased and the local committee, and the use of the railway to Newport, the remainder of the line not being in the hands of the company; but if the contractor for the remainder of the line from Newport to Achill could be arranged with, the trucks would be allowed to run on.
 A mounted policeman was despatched to Newport to make the necessary arrangements and a satisfactory reply was expected before morning.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: And despite being a "Balfour Line", it's Irish gauge, not narrow gauge.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Lots of photos here including ours. NGWR Station Archive

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: At a hearing before the Privy Council in 1892, the chief engineer for M G W railway Company  stated that men employed in railway construction (presumably such as she ones pictured here) were paid 14s a week, but it was difficult to retain them or find new men in the spring "because they had work at home" . Although this was a Balfour line, and not MGW, the rates and conditions would surely be similar.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This old line has been re-opened as a greenway/cycling path from Westport out to Achill, but they did not reopen the tunnels, too big a job, I suppose: In Newport an official access point is located to the left just off the N59 traveling in the direction of Westport located approximately 2km from Newport town.

comment.author: 93406327@N04
comment._content: mgwr.weebly.com/photos4.html Newport Station , Co. Mayo The Westport line was extended to Achill Sound in the 1890s. and this was one of the so-called 'Balfour Lines', called after Arthur J. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland during the years 1887-91, who introduced the Act providing State assistance for the construction of narrow gauge lines to disadvantaged areas. The first station on this extension was Newport which opened in February 1894. On of the most striking features of the Newport section of the line is the Viaduct which is featured in the picture on the left. Centre piece of Newport, the railway viaduct that once carried steam trains through Newport on their way to Achill, is now preserved as a walkway for native and visitor, to enjoy. It spans the Blackoak River, contains seven arches and cost £7,640 to build. The overall length of the viaduct is 305ft (92m) and the width 18ft 6in. The viaduct is constructed of local red sandstone with some limestone facings. The line was not opened until 1894 on completion of a nearby tunnel at the end of Newport Station.The first train crossed the bridge in February, 1894, and it was finally closed in September 1937.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
Excellent photograph. 
The track appears laid as it is, known as 'flat-bottom rail' which featured no chairs attached to the sleepers. This type of track was eventually replaced throughout the system, but lightly used lines like that to Achill and Clifden were never upgraded and by the 1930s were totally life-expired, resulting in their premature demise (Achill line closing in 1937). The sleepers are covered in spoil and gravel, which in those days was a lot finer type than today. I also see there is a check rail visible to prevent any derailments. 
The tunnels at Newport were two of only four constructed on the Midland Great Western, the others located at Galway, and Cross Gunns, Dublin.
